title: What is the Nandinagari script? - Quora

response.answer_text: Nandinagari was a Brahmi Based script that was used in southern India from the 11th to the 19th Century CE for producing manuscripts in sanskrit. It was used in southern Maharashtra, Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh. This script was the official script of the Vijayanagara Empire(1346-1646). This script was also used to write Kannada in the Vijayanagara Empire. It is one of the official scripts of the Udupi Aštta mutts along with tigalari script. Nandinagari is very similar to devanagari and other scripts of the Nagari group such as Gujarati script and Eastern Nagari scripts. This script was also used to write Konkani and Kannada when Goa was under the Vijayanagara Empire. Nandinagari is a Brahmic script derived from Nāgarī script which appeared in the 7th century AD. This script and its variants were used in the central Deccan region and south India, and an abundance of Sanskrit manuscripts in Nandinagari have been discovered but remain untransliterated. Sister system: Devanagari Parent systems: Brahmi alphabet > Northern Brahmi > Nagari > Nandinagari Direction: Left-to-right Languages: Sanskrit
